intro: Tragacantha falcinella, commonly known as the Persian gum tree, is a species of flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers and woody, thorny stems. The plant produces a resinous gum, which has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a natural adhesive. Its leaves are pinnately compound, and it thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, making it well adapted to harsh climates.
